Research article Position-controlled non-metal single atoms on MXene enable high-performance oxygen reduction electrocatalysis Guangxu Yao Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft 1 Jin Wan Formal analysis 1 Yangjun Luo Formal analysis Dong Liu Formal analysis Guolong Qiu Formal analysis Huijuan Zhang Formal analysis Yu Wang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Conceptualization School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Power Transmission Equipment Technology, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering State Key Laboratory of Power Transmission Equipment Technology Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Power Transmission Equipment Technology, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400044, PR China 1 These authors contributed equally to this work. Graphical abstract Different load positions result in different performances. Strategic localization of catalytically active sites within single-atom catalyst (SAC) architectures represents a pivotal determinant of material performance, particularly in two-dimensional (2D) substrates like MXenes, which offer intricate structural complexity and multifarious anchoring potentialities. Despite the burgeoning interest in non-metallic single-atom catalysts, a comprehensive understanding of site-specific loading mechanisms and their consequential catalytic implications remains substantially unexplored. Herein, we systematically investigate the precise incorporation of economically viable non-metallic elements—tellurium (Te) and arsenic (As)—onto Ti3C2 MXene, a prototypical 2D material characterized by exceptional structural versatility. Our methodology delineates a nuanced approach to controllable single-atom immobilization, strategically differentiating between vacancy-embedded and surface-supported configurations. Through meticulous experimental design, we demonstrate that Te single atoms strategically integrated within titanium vacancies (C-TeSA-T) manifest superior Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) electrocatalytic performance compared to surface-anchored counterparts (W-TeSA-T). Comprehensive characterization revealed remarkable electrocatalytic metrics, including a half-wave potential of 0.88 V vs. RHE and a limiting current density of 5.65 mA/cm2. Synergistic Density Functional Theory (DFT) computations and multi-potential X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopic (XPS) analyses elucidated the intrinsic mechanistic landscape, conclusively identifying Te single atoms as primary catalytic centers and delineating the rate-determining reaction trajectory. This systematic investigation not only introduces an innovative paradigm for designing cost-effective non-metallic catalysts but also provides fundamental mechanistic insights into the intricate relationship between active site localization and catalytic performance, thereby advancing our fundamental understanding of site-specific catalysis in two-dimensional materials. Keywords Non-metallic single-atom catalysts Mxenes support Oxygen Reduction Reaction Te As Data availability The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding authors upon reasonable request. 1 Introduction The pursuit of efficient and economically viable catalysts remains a central challenge in energy conversion and storage technologies [1–5]. The oxygen reduction reaction, fundamental to metal-air batteries and fuel cells, exemplifies this challenge through its inherently complex four-electron pathway and sluggish kinetics. While precious metal catalysts have traditionally dominated this space, their prohibitive costs, accounting for up to 50 % of fuel cell stack expenses, have necessitated the exploration of alternative materials that can achieve comparable performance at significantly reduced costs [6–9]. Recent advances in non-metal single-atom catalysis have emerged as a promising direction for addressing these challenges [10–14]. The strategic deployment of isolated non-metal atoms on conductive substrates maximizes atomic utilization efficiency while enabling precise control over structure–property relationships [15,16]. This approach has demonstrated remarkable versatility across various electrochemical processes, from hydrogen evolution to carbon dioxide reduction, with performance metrics approaching or exceeding those of conventional precious metal catalysts. Notable achievements include phosphorus single atoms supported on 2D Mo2C for hydrogen evolution, and selenium single atoms on nitrogen-doped carbon nanosheets achieving exceptional CO2 reduction efficiency, highlighting the broad applicability of this strategy [17–19]. Among non-metal elements, tellurium (Te) represents a particularly promising candidate for ORR catalysis due to its distinctive physicochemical properties. Its larger atomic radius and electronic configuration ([Kr]4d105s25p4) result in more diffuse valence orbitals compared to lighter Group VIA elements, facilitating enhanced oxygen molecule interactions. The metalloid nature of Te provides an optimal balance between metallic and non-metallic characteristics, while its variable oxidation states enable flexible electron transfer processes crucial for the multi-electron ORR pathway. Additionally, the larger polarizability of Te atoms enhances the modulation of electron density distribution at active sites, particularly beneficial for oxygen activation and subsequent protonation steps. These intrinsic properties, combined with its cost-effectiveness—approximately 1/500th the cost of platinum—position Te as an attractive element for developing efficient ORR catalysts. MXenes, an emerging class of two-dimensional materials derived from MAX phases, offer ideal platforms for single-atom catalyst development [20–25]. Their chemical composition (Mn + 1XnTx) and unique surface chemistry, featuring abundant terminal groups and inherent structural vacancies, provide multiple potential anchoring sites for single atoms. While previous studies have successfully demonstrated single-atom loading on MXene surfaces, they have predominantly focused on surface-confined architectures, limiting our understanding of how atomic position influences catalytic performance [26]. The impact of different anchoring sites—including surface, edge, and interlayer positions—on electronic structure, stability, and catalytic activity remains largely unexplored, representing a critical knowledge gap in the field [27–30]. This advancement is driven by the unique advantages of atomic dispersion, which maximizes atom utilization efficiency and enables precise structure–property relationships. Notable achievements include our team's previous work on P single atoms supported on 2D Mo2C for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [31], achieving a low overpotential of 85 mV at 10 mA cm2. We also successfully demonstrated the upcycling of arsenic from wastewater by anchoring As single atoms on defect-rich porous carbon, achieving exceptional ORR performance in hydrogen fuel cells with a half-wave potential approaching that of commercial Pt/C [32]. The versatility of non-metal single-atom catalysts is further exemplified by Zhao's group's work on I atoms on nickel iodide for HER [33], Yang's team's demonstration of Se single atoms on N-doped 2D carbon nanosheets achieving > 90 % Faradaic efficiency for CO2 reduction to CO [34], and Han's group's devon frameworks showing remarkable ORR activity with a half-wave potential of 0.85 V vs. RHE [35]. The electronic structure and coordination environment of non-metal single atoms can be finely tuned to catalyze different reactions efficiently [35,36]. This tunability arises from the strong electronic coupling between the single atoms and their support materials. For instance, the same non-metal element can exhibit distinct catalytic behaviors depending on its local coordination environment, as demonstrated by various Se-based single-atom catalysts showing high activity for both ORR and CO2 reduction reactions [34,35,37]. These studies collectively demonstrate the feasibility of reducing precious metal usage while maintaining, or even enhancing, catalytic performance [38–40]. Currently, some researchers are deepening their studies on atomic metal-nonmetal catalytic pairs. For example, the Wang team has developed an efficient catalyst composed of coupled metal and nonmetal atoms [41]. The Ir1.1/NPG they prepared achieved a current density of 358 mA−2 at 0.8 V in an H2–air battery. Meanwhile, Yang's team has theoretically demonstrated that nonmetal coordination can regulate the electronic properties of metal single atoms. Mo@B4C exhibits the most outstanding water decomposition performance [42]. The precise control of atom loading position represents a frontier in catalyst design, as subtle variations in the local coordination environment can dramatically influence electronic properties and, consequently, catalytic performance. Traditional approaches have typically resulted in random distribution or surface-confined loading of single atoms, limiting our ability to optimize these promising catalytic systems. The development of strategies for site-specific loading of non-metal single atoms onto different positions of MXene materials thus represents a crucial step toward rational catalyst design. Here, we present a comprehensive strategy for precise loading of non-metal single atoms onto distinct sites of MXene materials, demonstrating its versatility with both tellurium and arsenic. Through systematic variation of Ti3AlC2 etching conditions and meticulous regulation of environmental parameters, we achieved unprecedented control over atomic positioning within the MXene structure. This approach enables selective loading at surface, and edge, as validated through the successful synthesis of both Te-based (C-TeSA-T, W-TeSA-T) and As-based (C-AsSA-T, W-AsSA-T) single-atom catalysts, establishing a foundation for future exploration of site-dependent catalytic behavior across different non-metal elements. The successful preparation of these distinct single-atom systems demonstrates the broad applicability of our strategy across different non-metal elements, offering a universal approach for precise atomic architecture control in two-dimensional materials. Focusing on the Te-based system as a proof of concept, our C-TeSA-T catalyst exhibited exceptional ORR performance in alkaline media, achieving a half-wave potential of 0.88 V, surpassing previous non-precious metal catalysts. Detailed structural characterization and theoretical calculations reveal that the enhanced performance stems from optimal electronic coupling between Te atoms and specific MXene sites, highlighting the importance of precise atomic positioning in catalyst design. When integrated into practical devices, the C-TeSA-T catalyst demonstrated remarkable performance and stability. In liquid zinc-air batteries, the system achieved an impressive open-circuit voltage of 1.54 V and a maximum power density of 180.5 mW cm-2, maintaining stable operation for nearly two weeks. Furthermore, flexible zinc-air batteries incorporating this catalyst exhibited exceptional mechanical robustness, showing only 0.1 V voltage degradation after extensive bending cycles and reliable operation beyond 100 h. These findings not only establish the importance of site-specific atomic loading in catalyst design but also provide a versatile framework for developing high-performance, cost-effective electrocatalysts for practical energy applications. The strategies developed herein open new avenues for precise control of atomic architecture in two-dimensional materials, potentially extending beyond Te and As to other non-metal elements, thereby advancing the broader field of electrocatalysis. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals and materials Sulfur powder (purity ≥ 99.7 %), tellurium dioxide powder (purity ≥ 99.9 %), sodium arsenite powder (purity ≥ 90 %), titanium powder (purity ≥ 99.9 %), aluminum powder (purity ≥ 99.9 %), carbon powder (purity ≥ 99.9 %), hydrochloric acid (purity ≥ 30 %), and lithium fluoride (A.R.) were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, purity ≥ 99.5 %) was provided by Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. Potassium hydroxide (purity ≥ 95 %) and anhydrous ethanol (purity ≥ 99.5 %) were obtained from Chengdu Kelong Chemical Co., Ltd. Deoxygenated water was prepared in our laboratory. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of high-purity Ti3AlC2 Initially, titanium powder, aluminum powder, and carbon powder are weighed in a ratio of 3:1.06:1.9 and transferred into a beaker. An appropriate amount of anhydrous ethanol is added, and the mixture is stirred for 3 h to form a viscous, black paste-like substance. Subsequently, the paste is placed in a vacuum drying oven and desiccated at 85 °C under vacuum conditions for 15 h. Following this, 15 g of the dried sample powder is introduced into a cylindrical graphite mold. The apparatus is programmed to increase temperature at a rate of 10 °C per minute, with argon gas flowing as a protective atmosphere. The reaction is maintained at 1300 °C under a pressure of 35 MPa for 2 h. Finally, after natural cooling, the resultant black bulk solid is pulverized into powder and sieved, yielding high-purity Ti3AlC2 powder with a particle size of 300 mesh. 2.2.2 Cooling strategies for the synthesis of multilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets First, dissolve 2 g of LiF in a 40 mL test tube containing a 9 M concentrated hydrochloric acid solution, and continue stirring for 20 min to ensure complete mixing. Next, gradually add 2 g of high-purity Ti3AlC2 powder to the mixture and stir at 40 °C for 24 h. Then, perform no fewer than 10 cycles of centrifugation and continuous washing with deoxygenated water until the pH of the supernatant reaches approximately 6.5–7.5. Finally, vacuum dry the mixture for 20 h to obtain the crude product powder. To remove surface F groups as much as possible, weigh 2 g of the crude product and immerse it in a 1.8 M KOH solution (50 mL) while stirring for 12 h. Perform no fewer than 10 cycles of centrifugation and continuous washing with deoxygenated water until the pH of the supernatant reaches approximately 6.5–7.5, resulting in a sludge-like precipitate. Finally, vacuum dry the mixture for 20 h to obtain the crude product powder, which is the multilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets prepared via the cooling Strategies. 2.2.3 Warming strategies for the synthesis of multilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets First, add 500 mg of high-purity Ti3AlC2 powder into a 100 mL hydrothermal reaction vessel, followed by the addition of approximately 40 mL of 27 M KOH. After thorough stirring for 30 min, transfer the reaction vessel to a muffle furnace. Set the temperature to increase at a rate of 10 °C per minute until it reaches 180 °C, and maintain this temperature for 2 h. Then, increase the temperature at a rate of 5 °C per minute to 210 °C and hold for 3 h. Finally, raise the temperature at a rate of 5 °C per minute to 240 °C and react for 4 h before stopping the heating and allowing it to cool naturally. Subsequently, perform centrifugation and washing with deoxygenated water no fewer than 10 times until the pH of the supernatant reaches approximately 6.5–7.5, resulting in a sludge-like precipitate. Finally, subject the precipitate to vacuum drying for 20 h to obtain the crude product powder, which is the multilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets prepared via the warming strategies. 2.2.4 Synthesis of C-T and W-T catalysts The synthesis of monolayer Ti3C2Tx nanosheets is achieved through intercalation-assisted exfoliation, exemplified here using the cooling strategy approach. Initially, 2 g of multilayer, clay-like Ti3C2Tx is dispersed in 100 mL of DMSO and subjected to stirring for 24 h under an argon atmosphere at ambient temperature. Subsequently, the mixture undergoes high-power sonication for 4 h, resulting in a dark suspension that exhibits solid–liquid separation after 1 h of sedimentation. The supernatant dark liquid is then carefully extracted and centrifuged. The resultant solid undergoes extensive washing with ethanol and deoxygenated water, followed by lyophilization to obtain the powder sample, designated as C-T. An identical procedure is applied to the multilayer Ti3C2Tx MXene nanosheets prepared via the heating strategy, with the resulting product designated as W-T. 2.2.5 Synthesis of C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T catalysts The catalyst C-TeSA-T is synthesized via a negative pressure confinement strategy. Initially, TeO2 powder and C-T are positioned separately within a tubular furnace, ensuring that the TeO2 powder is upstream of the gas flow. Argon gas is then purged through the furnace for a predetermined duration. Subsequently, the furnace inlets and outlets are sealed, maintaining a pressure of −1 MPa. The temperature is ramped at a rate of 5 °C per minute to 600 °C and held isothermally for 1.5 h. Finally, the system is allowed to cool naturally to ambient temperature before the negative pressure is released. A similar methodology is employed for the synthesis of catalyst W-TeSA-T. However, it is crucial to note that the isothermal temperature is maintained at 450 °C, and the negative pressure condition is omitted. 2.2.6 Synthesis of C-AsSA-T and W-AsSA-T catalysts Similar to the previous procedure, the catalyst C-AsSA-T was also synthesized using a negative pressure confinement strategy. Sodium arsenite powder and C-T were placed separately in a tube furnace, ensuring that the sodium arsenite powder was positioned upstream of the gas flow. Argon gas was then introduced into the furnace for a predetermined duration. Subsequently, the furnace's inlet and outlet were sealed, maintaining a pressure of −1 MPa. The temperature was increased at a rate of 5 °C per minute to 650 °C and held under isothermal conditions for 1.5 h. Finally, the system was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, after which the negative pressure was released. The synthesis of the catalyst W-AsSA-T followed a similar method. However, it is important to note that the isothermal temperature was maintained at 620 °C, and the negative pressure condition was omitted. 2.3 Characterization To examine and evaluate the catalysts, a range of techniques were employed to analyze the structure, composition, and properties of the samples. A material's composition was determined using X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X'Pert Powder) through analysis of its diffraction pattern. In order to examine the external characteristics of the materials, a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, JEOL JSM-7800F) was utilized. The microstructure of these materials at the atomic level was probed using spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI Titan ChemiSTEM). By analyzing the X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), specific elements present in the sample are identified based on the characteristic X-rays emitted by the elements in the sample under electron beam bombardment. Additionally, through the observation of molecular vibrations, a Raman spectrum (wavenumber of 100–2000 cm−1, Horiba LabRAM HR Evolution, 532 nm) was obtained and utilized to gain insights into the internal structure of materials. Nitrogen isothermal adsorption and desorption curves (BET, MicrotracBEL) were found to be effective measures of significant parameters like pore size, pore volume, and specific surface area of the catalyst. ICP-OES6300,Thermo Fisher Scientific (inductively coupled plasma photoemission spectroscopy) was employed to accurately ascertain both metallic and non-metallic elemental compositions. Finally, to analyze the chemistry and chemical state of the catalyst surface, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi from Thermo scientific) was utilized. The information about thickness with atomic layer precision of the catalysts was obtained by characterizing the samples using atomic force microscopy (AFM, MFP-3D-BIO). Quasi-operando XPS analysis of the C-TeSA-T catalyst was performed at different applied potentials. The reverse side of the SiN4 window (coated with the catalyst on a gold/titanium substrate) faced the interior of the electrochemical cell. The three-electrode configuration consisted of a silver/silver chloride reference electrode housed in a Luggin capillary and a carbon rod counter electrode. The silver/silver chloride electrode was isolated on one side of the sample chamber. The C-TeSA-T sample was immersed in oxygen-saturated 0.1 M electrolyte, after which the reactor was subjected to vacuum treatment. Prior to XPS measurements at each target potential (0.5 V, 0.7 V, 0.9 V, 1.1 V vs. RHE), the electrode was electrochemically stabilized through 4-minute polarization. Spectral data acquisition was conducted after reaching steady-state conditions. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The ink preparation involves a hybrid methodology. Initially, a mixture comprising 1 mg of catalyst, 20 μL of isopropanol, 20 μL of 5 wt% Nafion, and 160 μL of ultrapure water undergoes sonication for 60 min. Subsequently, 15 μL of the resultant ink is deposited onto a rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE), which has been subjected to appropriate polishing to ensure surface cleanliness. The loading is precisely controlled at 0.38 mg cm−2, followed by natural desiccation for 60 min prior to utilization. The electrochemical characterization employs a three-electrode configuration (AFMSRCE, PINE Instruments, USA). A mercury/mercury oxide electrode serves as the reference, while a graphite electrode functions as the counter electrode. The catalyst-loaded RRDE acts as the working electrode. All potentials reported herein are calibrated against the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) as per equation (1) and are subject to IR compensation. (1) E R H E = E θ + 0.0591 p H + 0.098 The Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) investigations are conducted in 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. To obtain stable linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves, 50 cycles are performed at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. Electrochemical tests were performed by using an electrochemical workstation (CHI760E) with a three-electrode system at room temperature. Tested with iR compensation (80 % compensation level). Here, Ir and Id represent the ring and disk currents, respectively. The current collection efficiency (N) of the platinum ring is 0.38. Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) studies are performed in O2-saturated 1 M KOH solution. LSV curves are acquired at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm and a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. The long-term stability of the catalysts is investigated through cyclic voltammetry (CV). The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) is determined by CV measurements at various scan rates. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is conducted over a frequency range of 0.01 Hz to 100,000 Hz. Chronoamperometry is employed for methanol poisoning experiments and durability tests. 2.5 Zinc-Air battery evaluation The assembly of conventional rechargeable liquid zinc-air batteries proceeds as follows: A homogeneous mixture of 2 mg catalyst, 40 μL Nafion (5 wt%), and 360 μL anhydrous ethanol is subjected to sonication. The resulting catalyst ink is uniformly deposited onto a polytetrafluoroethylene-treated carbon paper, serving as the cathode. A polished zinc plate with a thickness of 0.25 mm functions as the anode. The electrolyte consists of a mixture of 6 mol/L KOH and 0.2 mol/L zinc acetate solutions. A nickel foam sheet, identical in dimensions to the zinc plate, acts as the current collector. These components are assembled to form the zinc-air battery. For comparison, a similar battery is constructed using a 1:1 mass ratio of Pt/C + RuO2. Long-cycle experiments are conducted at a constant charge and discharge current density of 5 mA cm−1, with each cycle lasting 20 min. The specific capacity was calculated by recording the consumption of Zn foil during continuous discharge at a current density of 50 mA cm−2 and by using the following equation: Specific capacity = current × test time/weight of consumed Zn. The flexible solid-state zinc-air battery assembly follows this protocol: A polished zinc foil of 0.1 mm thickness serves as the negative electrode, while a carbon cloth loaded with catalyst and nickel foam collectively function as the air electrode. The gel electrolyte is prepared by dissolving 7 g of PVA powder in 40 mL of ultrapure water, stirring for 2 h at 93 °C to ensure complete dissolution. Subsequently, 20 mL of the liquid zinc-air battery electrolyte is added, followed by an additional 30 min of stirring. Upon cooling, the liquid is refrigerated for 2 h to obtain the gel electrolyte. The flexible solid-state zinc-air battery is assembled by securing a gel piece of identical dimensions to the zinc foil between the zinc foil and air electrode. Long-cycle experiments are performed at a constant charge and discharge current density of 2 mA cm−1, with each cycle lasting 20 min. 2.6 Computational methods First-principles calculations were conducted using VASP-5.4.4. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to describe exchange–correlation interactions. All computations accounted for electron spin polarization. During structural relaxation, the energy convergence criterion was set to 10-5 eV, and atoms were relaxed until residual forces were below 0.03 eV/Å. A plane-wave cutoff energy of 500 eV was used. The partial carbon defect model referenced prior studies. To prevent mirror interactions between periodic images, a 15 Å vacuum layer was added along the z-axis. Van der Waals interactions were incorporated using Grimme's DFT-D3 scheme. Brillouin zone integration utilized a Γ-centered 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh for structural optimizations and a finer 4 × 4 × 1 mesh for electronic property calculations. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis route of each catalyst, electron microscopic characterization of C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T The synthesis of single-atom catalysts commenced with granulometric optimization of Ti3AlC2 precursor powder to achieve homogeneous particle size distribution, a critical parameter for subsequent etching protocols (Fig. S1a). We established two distinct methodologies—cryogenic and thermally-activated approaches—for the selective etching of Ti3AlC2 to synthesize multilayered Ti3C2 as an optimal intermediate for subsequent catalytic functionalization (Fig. S1b). The cryogenic protocol utilized a LiF/HCl binary etchant system, necessitating precise stoichiometric control and temporal optimization. Excessive etching parameters induced undesirable perforation of the nanosheets (Fig. S2a), while insufficient conditions resulted in incomplete delamination (Fig. S2b). Conversely, the thermally-activated approach employing KOH exhibited enhanced parametric tolerance without compromising structural fidelity. Post-etching, the multilayered Ti3C2 underwent intercalation-assisted exfoliation under inert atmosphere, followed by ultrasonication-mediated delamination. The supernatant was subsequently isolated, purified, and lyophilized to obtain monolayer Ti3C2 nanosheets (Fig. S1c). Successful delamination was confirmed through colloidal stability analysis—properly exfoliated Ti3C2 exhibited stable colloidal dispersions (Fig. S1d, left vial), while unsuccessful preparations demonstrated poor aqueous dispersibility (Fig. S1d, right vial). Both cryogenic-treated (C-T) and thermally-treated (W-T) samples exhibited excellent colloidal stability. The synthetic protocols for C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T are depicted in Fig. 1 a. Using C-TeSA-T as a model system, the procedure involved spatial positioning of C-T (1 mmol) downstream and TeO2 (10 mmol) upstream in a tube furnace under regulated argon flow. The system was evacuated and maintained under negative pressure to ensure atmospheric control. During thermal ramping, TeO2 underwent vapor-phase transport, facilitating atomic Te species interaction with Ti3C2 surface defect sites, culminating in single-atom anchoring. While W-TeSA-T synthesis followed analogous protocols, it required specific parametric modifications: thermal treatment at 450 °C under ambient pressure conditions. The optimization of TeO2 concentration and annealing temperature proved critical, as excess TeO2 combined with lower thermal treatment resulted in undesirable Te cluster formation on the Ti3C2 surface, as evidenced in Fig. S3a–b. Initial characterization of Te single-atom catalysts synthesized via both methodologies revealed comparable morphological characteristics at low magnification. Representative SEM analysis of C-TeSA-T demonstrated the characteristic morphology (Fig. 1b). AFM measurements were employed to quantify sample thickness, with single-layer Ti3C2 nanosheets expected to exhibit vertical heights approximating the cumulative diameter of three Ti atoms, two C atoms, and two heteroatoms. Analysis of a representative region revealed a nanosheet thickness of ∼3.5 nm (Fig. 1c), confirming the monolayer nature of the catalyst substrate. Low-magnification transmission electron microscopy analysis confirmed these findings, with the monolayer Mxene as shown in Fig. 1d. The elemental mapping demonstrates the uniform distribution of C, Ti, O, and Te elements on the Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets (Fig. 1e, g). Simultaneously, the EDS spectrum also confirms the presence of C, Ti, O, and Te elements on the Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets (Fig. 1f). While morphological characteristics appeared consistent between preparation methods, HAADF-STEM analysis at high magnification revealed distinct structural differences between C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T. The cryogenic strategy employed for C-TeSA-T synthesis, utilizing HCl/LiF etching at 40 °C, generated vacancy defects in the multilayer Ti3C2 nanosheets. The resultant C-T surface exhibited Ti vacancy defects and defect clusters of varying dimensions, denoted by yellow circles in Fig. 1h. These defects functioned as capture sites for Te atoms at 600 °C, preventing surface oxygen-mediated adsorption. Microscopy analysis confirmed this observation, with Te atoms (higher atomic number) appearing as bright spots. Fig. 1i reveals dispersed Te atoms (red circles) alongside various-sized defects (yellow circles). Higher magnification analysis of selected regions (green dashed rectangle) demonstrated Te atoms (purple dots) exhibiting enhanced brightness compared to adjacent Ti atoms (cyan dots), corroborated by experimental imaging and simulation models (Fig. 1j). Conversely, the thermally-activated strategy for W-TeSA-T synthesis, employing KOH-mediated etching of amphoteric Al in a sealed hydrothermal system, produced W-T surfaces devoid of Ti vacancy defects (Fig. 1k). The modified conditions facilitated oxygen-mediated Te atom capture, evidenced in Fig. 1l (red circles). Higher magnification revealed interstitial Te atom positioning between Ti atoms, validated through experimental and simulated imaging (Fig. 1m). In the simulated images, based on the differences in atomic number, the Te atomic columns exhibit higher contrast compared to the Ti-C atomic columns. The visibility of the contrast difference is further enhanced through pseudocolor image processing techniques. The consistency between the experimental and simulated images provides clear evidence that Te atoms are anchored at different sites. This detailed simulation methodology and analysis support our conclusions (Fig. 1j, Fig. 1m). In summary, while low-magnification analysis suggested morphological similarity between C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T, nanoscale characterization revealed distinct Te single-atom configurations: C-TeSA-T exhibited Te atoms embedded within Ti vacancy defects, while W-TeSA-T demonstrated interstitial Te atom positioning mediated by surface oxygen species. 3.2 Various basic characterizations of catalysts XRD analysis was conducted to elucidate the structural characteristics of the catalysts. The synthesized Ti3AlC2 powder exhibited diffraction patterns consistent with the standard PDF52-0875 reference (Fig. S4). Both C-TeSA-T and W-TeSA-T demonstrated characteristic MXene signatures, with their (002) diffraction peaks showing a pronounced leftward shift compared to the parent Ti3AlC2 powder, manifesting as intense signals around 6°. This peak shift confirms successful exfoliation to single-layer structures. Notably, neither catalyst displayed diffraction patterns corresponding to Te species (PDF18-1324), suggesting the absence of Te clusters and supporting atomic-level Te dispersion [43,44]. XPS analysis provided crucial insights into Te atom loading mechanisms. C-TeSA-T exhibited a distinct Te-C peak at approximately 287.2 eV [45], which was absent in W-TeSA-T (Fig. S5). This observation aligns with the different synthesis pathways: In C-TeSA-T, the HCl/LiF etching process completely removed aluminum while creating Ti vacancy defects due to Ti's relative corrosion resistance. These defects inevitably captured Te species, resulting in Te-C bond formation, corroborating microscopy observations of Te atoms occupying Ti vacancy sites. Conversely, W-TeSA-T, prepared using concentrated KOH etching, showed no Ti vacancy defects, consistent with Te atoms positioned between Ti atoms rather than forming Te-C bonds. Additional peaks at 286 eV and 282.0 eV were attributed to C-O and C-Ti bonds, respectively. BET surface area measurements, determined through nitrogen adsorption–desorption experiments, revealed significant differences between the catalysts (Fig. S6). C-TeSA-T exhibited a higher specific surface area of 98.3 m2/g compared to W-TeSA-T's 78.8 m2/g. This substantial difference stems from C-TeSA-T's irregular surface topology, where abundant Ti vacancy defects and defect clusters contribute to increased surface area. Raman spectroscopy analysis of the ID/IG ratio provided valuable information about structural quality. The D-band (∼1350 cm-1) corresponds to structural defects, while the G-band (∼1580 cm-1) reflects sp2 hybridized carbon bonds (Fig. S7 a). C-TeSA-T demonstrated a higher ID/IG ratio (1.47) compared to W-TeSA-T (1.22), indicating greater structural defect concentration, potentially facilitating enhanced electron transfer in oxygen reduction reactions. XAS investigations revealed detailed insights into Te species dispersion. The XANES spectra of the Te K-edge (Fig. 2 a) showed absorption edge energies between Te foil and TeO2, indicating Te oxidation states between 0 and + 4. From the Te K-edge XANES analysis of the average oxidation state, the precise determination of the Te valence state is as follows: The results indicate that the average Te oxidation state is 1.4 for C-TeSA-T and 2.7 for W-TeSA-T (Fig. S7 b). C-TeSA-T exhibited lower average Te oxidation states, attributed to extensive defect formation and reduced oxygen interaction. EXAFS analysis provided further structural insights, with k3-weighted Fourier transform spectra (Fig. 2b) showing no Te-Te scattering paths, confirming the absence of Te clusters. Both catalysts exhibited primary peaks at 1.45 Å, corresponding to Te-C/O scattering paths. Fitting analysis revealed coordination numbers of 1.8 for W-TeSA-T (Fig. 2c) and 3.1 for C-TeSA-T (Fig. 2d), confirming unsaturated coordination structures beneficial for catalysis. Wavelet transform analysis (Fig. 2e) further differentiated the local bonding environments [44,46]. To demonstrate methodological versatility, analogous arsenic-based catalysts were synthesized and characterized. XANES spectra (Fig. 2f) of As foil, NaAsO2, and both catalysts showed partial oxidation of As single atoms, with edge positions between As foil and NaAsO2. C-AsSA-T displayed lower As oxidation states compared to W-AsSA-T, consistent with its Ti-defect-rich structure. Fourier-transformed k2-weighted EXAFS spectra (Fig. 2g) exhibited characteristic peaks at 1.3 Å (As-C/O bonds), distinctly different from As-As bonds at 2.2 Å, confirming atomic dispersion. Fitting analysis revealed coordination numbers of 2.8 for C-AsSA-T (Fig. 2h) and 1.9 for W- AsSA −T (Fig. 2i), demonstrating unsaturated coordination environments. Wavelet transform analysis (Fig. 2j) provided additional bonding environment insights, with complete fitting parameters summarized in Table S1. These comprehensive analyses validate both synthetic approaches' efficacy across different elemental species, demonstrating consistent patterns in coordination environments and oxidation states between congener and non-congener elements. 3.3 Electrochemical testing of catalysis We conducted a comprehensive evaluation of the oxygen reduction reaction performance of our synthesized tellurium single-atom catalysts, with a particular focus on the exceptional activity of C-TeSA-T. The objective was to determine the viability of these catalysts as efficient and stable electrocatalysts for potential applications in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. Using a standard three-electrode electrochemical setup in a 0.1 M KOH aqueous solution, we performed CV and LSV to assess and compare the catalytic capabilities of the synthesized materials. In the initial CV experiments conducted without electrode rotation, we saturated the electrolyte solution with either nitrogen or oxygen gas to establish inert and oxidative conditions, respectively. Under nitrogen saturation, all catalysts exhibited featureless voltammograms with no observable ORR peaks, indicating the absence of electrochemical activity in the potential window studied (Fig. S8). This confirmed that any subsequent catalytic activity could be attributed solely to the presence of oxygen. Conversely, upon oxygen saturation, all catalysts displayed pronounced cathodic peaks corresponding to the ORR. Notably, C-TeSA-T presented the most significant peak at the most positive potential among all samples tested. This positive shift in peak potential and increased peak current density highlight the superior ORR catalytic activity of C-TeSA-T compared to its counterparts, suggesting a more favorable interaction with oxygen molecules and more efficient electron transfer processes. To further investigate the catalytic performance under controlled mass transport conditions, we performed LSV measurements using a rotating disk electrode at a rotation speed of 1600 rpm (Fig. 3 a). The rotation of the electrode ensures a uniform diffusion layer and steady-state conditions, allowing for more accurate evaluation of the catalytic kinetics. The LSV curves revealed that C-TeSA-T achieved the highest limiting current density among all catalysts tested, indicating a higher catalytic efficiency and greater accessibility of active sites. The enhanced limiting current suggests that C-TeSA-T facilitates improved oxygen diffusion and electron transfer during the ORR process, which is critical for high-performance electrocatalysts. For a quantitative comparison of catalytic activity, we examined key parameters derived from the LSV data, specifically the E1/2 and the J k (Fig. 3b). The half-wave potential is a crucial parameter that reflects the overpotential required for the ORR to proceed and provides insights into the thermodynamic favorability of the reaction on the catalyst surface. A more positive E1/2 indicates a lower overpotential and, therefore, better catalytic activity. The kinetic current density, calculated using the K-L equation, isolates the intrinsic catalytic activity by removing mass transport limitations. C-TeSA-T exhibited an impressive half-wave potential of 0.88 V versus the RHE, surpassing the commercial Pt/C catalyst, which showed an E1/2 of 0.86 V. This 20 mV positive shift signifies a more energetically favorable ORR process on C-TeSA-T. Additionally, at a potential of 0.86 V, the kinetic current density for C-TeSA-T reached 5.65 mA cm-2, exceeding that of Pt/C, which was 5.50 mA cm-2. These results clearly demonstrate that C-TeSA-T not only matches but also outperforms the traditional Pt/C catalyst in terms of catalytic activity and efficiency, highlighting its potential as a cost-effective alternative for ORR applications. Supporting these findings, the Tafel plots derived from the LSV data provided further insights into the reaction kinetics (Fig. 3c). The Tafel slope is indicative of the rate-determining step in the ORR mechanism and is related to the transfer coefficient and the number of electrons involved in the rate-limiting step. C-TeSA-T exhibited a Tafel slope of 54.32 mV dec-1, which is significantly lower than the 69.34 mV dec-1 observed for Pt/C. A lower Tafel slope suggests faster reaction kinetics and more efficient catalytic processes. This implies that C-TeSA-T facilitates the ORR with a lower activation energy barrier, enhancing the overall reaction rate and catalytic efficiency. These kinetic advantages corroborate our earlier observations from the CV and LSV analyses. To elucidate the ORR mechanism facilitated by C-TeSA-T, we investigated the electron transfer number using RDE tests at varying rotation speeds ranging from 400 to 2400 rpm (Fig. 3d and Fig. S9). According to the K-L equations, the dependency of the limiting current density on the rotation speed allows for the calculation of the electron transfer number involved in the ORR. The linearity and parallelism of the K-L plots indicate consistent reaction kinetics across the tested potential range. The average electron transfer number for C-TeSA-T was calculated to be 3.86, which is very close to the ideal value of 4 for the complete reduction of oxygen to water. In comparison, the Pt/C catalyst exhibited an n value of 3.95. This near-four electron transfer pathway suggests that C-TeSA-T promotes a direct and efficient ORR process, minimizing the formation of undesirable hydrogen peroxide intermediates. Such a pathway is highly desirable for practical fuel cell applications, as it enhances energy efficiency and reduces potential degradation associated with peroxide species. Further confirming the selectivity of the ORR pathway, we measured the hydrogen peroxide yield and calculated the electron transfer number using a rotating ring-disk electrode technique (Fig. 3e). Across a potential range of 0.2 V to 0.8 V, the hydrogen peroxide yield for C-TeSA-T remained below 5 %, indicating minimal generation of peroxide byproducts. The electron transfer numbers derived from the RRDE data were consistent with the RDE results, further validating the efficient four-electron ORR pathway facilitated by C-TeSA-T. This high selectivity is crucial for the longevity and safety of fuel cells and metal-air batteries, as peroxide species can lead to membrane degradation and reduced performance. Understanding the relationship between the catalyst's surface properties and its electrochemical performance is vital. We investigated the ECSA of the catalysts by measuring the Cdl through CV tests at different scan rates (Fig. S10). The Cdl is proportional to the ECSA, reflecting the number of active sites available for the ORR. C-TeSA-T exhibited the highest Cdl value of 8.2 mF cm-2 (Fig. 3f), significantly higher than the other catalysts tested. This suggests that C-TeSA-T possesses a larger surface area with more accessible active sites, contributing to its superior catalytic performance. We employed EIS to analyze the charge transfer resistance (Rct) between the catalysts and the electrolyte (Fig. 3g). The Rct is a critical parameter that influences the rate of electron transfer during the ORR. A lower Rct indicates more efficient charge transfer and better catalytic activity. The Nyquist plots revealed that C-TeSA-T had the smallest charge transfer resistance of 28.34 Ω, outperforming W-TeSA-T (30.06 Ω), C-T (33.12 Ω), and W-T (65.46 Ω). This lower resistance is indicative of improved conductive pathways and electron transfer kinetics in C-TeSA-T, further explaining its enhanced ORR performance. We conducted multiple cycling experiments on the catalysts C-Te-T and W-Te-T. It was found that C-Te-T exhibited excellent stability, with only a 10 mV loss in half-wave potential after 10,000 durability tests, as shown in Fig. 3h. In contrast, the performance of W-Te-T, under a different loading method, was quite unsatisfactory; the LSV curve indicated that after 10,000 cycles, its performance had degraded to the same level as W-T, as illustrated in Fig. 3i. Through testing methods such as EDS, XPS and ICP, the content of each component in the two catalysts was clearly determined before and after the tests (Table S2). Weigh the mass of the two catalysts in their initial state, after 5000 cycles, and after 10,000 cycles. Then, based on their LSV curves, a comparison of the mass activity of the two catalysts is processed. It is evident that C-TeSA-T exhibits superior stability, as shown in Fig. 3j. After completing the 10,000-cycle test, both catalysts were observed under a spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscope. It is clear that the Te single atoms in C-TeSA-T remain in a single, independent state, as shown in Fig. S11a, while the Te single atoms in W-TeSA-T have almost entirely been lost, as shown in Fig. S11b. Therefore, the performance decline observed in the LSV tests correlates with that of W-T. To assess the durability and operational stability of the catalyst, we conducted methanol tolerance tests and long-term chronoamperometric measurements. In the methanol tolerance test (Fig. S12), methanol was added to the electrolyte once at approximately the 400th second of the measurement process. C-TeSA-T exhibited excellent stability, with only a minor fluctuation in current density and retaining 95 % of its initial current density after 1000 s. In stark contrast, the W-TeSA-T catalyst showed a significant drop in current density upon methanol addition, retaining only 71 % of its initial value. This demonstrates that C-TeSA-T has a high resistance to methanol crossover effects, making it particularly suitable for use in direct methanol fuel cells where methanol tolerance is essential. In the long-term stability test conducted under a constant high current density (Fig. 3k), C-TeSA-T maintained 90 % of its initial current density after 20,000 s (approximately 5.5 h) of continuous operation. The Pt/C catalyst, on the other hand, declined to 80 % of its initial current density over the same period and continued to show a downward trend. These results underscore the excellent operational stability and durability of C-TeSA-T, which are critical parameters for the practical deployment of electrocatalysts in energy conversion devices. In summary, our comprehensive electrochemical evaluations demonstrate that C-TeSA-T exhibits outstanding ORR performance, surpassing the commercial Pt/C catalyst in key aspects such as catalytic activity, reaction kinetics, durability, methanol tolerance, and electron transfer efficiency. The combination of high half-wave potential, low Tafel slope, efficient four-electron transfer pathway, excellent durability, and favorable charge transfer properties makes C-TeSA-T a highly promising candidate for next-generation electrocatalysts in fuel cells and metal-air batteries. This work has also been compared with other recent advanced studies (Fig. 3l) [29,47–53]. Its superior performance, coupled with the potential for cost-effective synthesis and scalability, positions C-TeSA-T as a viable alternative to traditional noble metal catalysts, paving the way for more sustainable and economically feasible energy conversion technologies. 3.4 Catalysts for metal-air batteries Comprehensive electrochemical evaluation of C-TeSA-T as an oxygen electrocatalyst was conducted in zinc-air battery configurations to assess its practical applicability. The battery assembly utilized a polished zinc anode and 6 mol/L KOH electrolyte supplemented with 0.2 mol/L acetic acid, following the configuration illustrated in Fig. 4 a. The C-TeSA-T-based system achieved an enhanced open-circuit voltage (OCV) of 1.54 V, exceeding the commercial Pt/C catalyst benchmark (1.51 V), indicating superior electrochemical potential for oxygen reduction reactions (Fig. 4b). Performance analysis revealed that the C-TeSA-T-based battery delivered an enhanced specific capacity of 798mA h g Z n - 1 , , surpassing the noble metal catalyst (757mA h g Z n - 1 ,) (Fig. 4c). Discharge polarization measurements demonstrated superior current density characteristics, with C-TeSA-T achieving a maximum power density of 180.5 mW cm-2, substantially outperforming the Pt/C catalyst's 134.6 mW cm-2 (Fig. 4d). Charge-discharge profile analysis (Fig. S13a) revealed reduced voltage gaps compared to Pt/C + RuO2, indicating enhanced energy efficiency and rechargeability. The system exhibited consistently superior voltage readings across varied discharge currents (Fig. S13b), demonstrating robust performance stability. Long-term durability assessment under 5 mA cm-2 current density revealed stable operation exceeding 340 h of continuous charge–discharge cycles (Fig. 4e), validating the catalyst's exceptional stability for extended energy storage applications. To address emerging flexible electronics applications, we fabricated a flexible zinc-air battery incorporating C-TeSA-T (Fig. 4f). The system demonstrated an enhanced open-circuit voltage of 1.36 V (Fig. 4g) compared to noble metal catalyst alternatives, with minimal voltage degradation (0.1 V) post-mechanical deformation (Fig. S14a). The battery successfully powered a small electric fan, demonstrating practical viability for low-power electronic applications (Fig. S14b). Subsequent tests revealed a power density of 89.6 mW cm-2 (Fig. 4h). This lays the foundation for potential applications in small devices. Performance evaluation under mechanical stress revealed remarkable stability, with charge–discharge profiles maintaining consistency across bending angles from 0° to 180° at 2 mA cm-2 current density (Fig. 4i). Extended durability testing demonstrated minimal voltage window expansion from 0.47 V to 0.53 V over 100 h of operation (Fig. 4j), confirming exceptional cycling stability. Comparative analysis with state-of-the-art catalysts reported in leading journals demonstrates the advanced performance characteristics of our system (Table S3). The integration of C-TeSA-T as an oxygen electrocatalyst demonstrates significant performance enhancements across critical metrics in both conventional and flexible zinc-air batteries. The catalyst's exceptional mechanical resilience and electrochemical stability position it as a promising candidate for next-generation energy storage applications, particularly in flexible electronics. Its superior performance compared to noble metal catalysts establishes a foundation for cost-effective, high-performance energy storage technologies. 3.5 Investigation of catalytic mechanisms Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations provided crucial insights into the significant performance differences between the two single-atom catalyst variants. The binding energy calculations (Fig. 5 a) revealed a substantial difference between C-TeSA-T (2.98 eV) and W-TeSA-T (0.54 eV). The markedly higher binding energy of C-TeSA-T, attributed to Te atoms anchored in Ti vacancies, indicates superior structural stability compared to W-TeSA-T. This theoretical prediction aligns with the observed electrochemical stability measurements, providing a fundamental explanation for the enhanced durability of C-TeSA-T during catalytic operations. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to identify and characterize the active sites in C-TeSA-T (Fig. 5b). A systematic positive shift in Te 3d binding energy was observed with decreasing applied potential. Notably, at 1.1 V, the Te binding energy exhibited a significant positive shift compared to the unbiased state, primarily attributed to oxygen species adsorption at Te active sites in an oxygen-saturated 0.1 M KOH solution. The progressive increase in Te binding energy observed between 0.9 V and 0.5 V corresponds to the gradual formation of oxygen-containing intermediates at Te sites. These systematic changes suggest that the exceptional catalytic activity of C-TeSA-T can be attributed to the incorporation of single-atom Te. Charge density difference analysis of Te and O species interactions in C-TeSA-T during the reaction process (Fig. 5c–e) revealed distinctive electron distribution patterns. The visualization, where yellow regions indicate electron enrichment and cyan regions represent electron depletion, demonstrated significant electron transfer from the substrate to Te species, triggering electron delocalization. This electronic restructuring likely modulates intermediate adsorption and hybridization, contributing to enhanced oxygen reduction reaction performance. These findings corroborate the earlier XPS analysis. The catalytic activity of single-atom Te for the four-electron coupled ORR pathway was evaluated through free energy diagrams, confirming the O2→*OOH→*O→*OH → H2O reaction sequence. At U = 1.23 V (Fig. 5f), the energy differences between reaction stages determined the Eads of various intermediates. C-TeSA-T demonstrated lower free energy barriers compared to C-T across all reaction steps. Most significantly, the rate-determining O2→*OOH step showed a substantially lower free energy barrier (0.447 eV) on the C-TeSA-T surface compared to C-T, indicating superior ORR kinetics. These theoretical calculations align with both XPS analysis and electrochemical experimental results, providing comprehensive evidence for the enhanced ORR performance of C-TeSA-T. In summary, preparing defects to capture single atoms as active sites to enhance stability and catalytic performance is a popular choice at present. For example, Huang's team is studying Fe single-atom catalysts [54]. Alternatively, transforming Mn-N4 into an Mn-N3 structure and introducing another element, as done by Kong's team, or changing the coordinating atoms or loading positions can also lead to significant performance improvements [55]. 4 Conclusion In this work, we have established a pioneering framework for understanding position-dependent catalytic behavior of non-metal single atoms on MXene surfaces through systematic investigation of Te and As atoms at distinct anchoring sites. Advanced characterization techniques, including HAADF-STEM and XAS, confirmed atomic dispersion and site-specific coordination environments, validating our strategic approach to controlled atomic positioning. The optimized C-TeSA-T catalyst, featuring Te single atoms precisely anchored in Ti vacancies, demonstrated exceptional ORR performance, achieving specific capacities approaching 800 mAh in zinc-air batteries—surpassing conventional precious metal catalysts in both efficiency and stability. Mechanistic investigations through combined theoretical calculations and in-situ XPS analysis revealed that Te single atoms in Ti vacancies serve as active sites, with O2-to-*OOH conversion as the rate-determining step. This optimal electronic configuration facilitates both O2 adsorption and subsequent protonation steps, underlying the superior catalytic activity. The remarkable stability of these systems, demonstrated through nearly two-week continuous operation and maintained performance under mechanical deformation in flexible devices, highlights their practical viability for next-generation energy applications. Beyond the specific Te and As systems investigated, this work establishes fundamental design principles for non-metal single-atom catalysts through strategic engineering of coordination environments. Our findings demonstrate that precise atomic positioning can enable cost-effective alternatives to precious metal catalysts, while providing a mechanistic framework for optimizing site-dependent catalytic behavior in two-dimensional materials. These insights offer a robust foundation for developing high-performance, economically viable electrocatalysts for energy conversion and storage applications. coredata.dc:description: Strategic localization of catalytically active sites within single-atom catalyst (SAC) architectures represents a pivotal determinant of material performance, particularly in two-dimensional (2D) substrates like MXenes, which offer intricate structural complexity and multifarious anchoring potentialities. Despite the burgeoning interest in non-metallic single-atom catalysts, a comprehensive understanding of site-specific loading mechanisms and their consequential catalytic implications remains substantially unexplored. Herein, we systematically investigate the precise incorporation of economically viable non-metallic elements—tellurium (Te) and arsenic (As)—onto Ti3C2 MXene, a prototypical 2D material characterized by exceptional structural versatility. Our methodology delineates a nuanced approach to controllable single-atom immobilization, strategically differentiating between vacancy-embedded and surface-supported configurations. Through meticulous experimental design, we demonstrate that Te single atoms strategically integrated within titanium vacancies (C-TeSA-T) manifest superior Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR) electrocatalytic performance compared to surface-anchored counterparts (W-TeSA-T). Comprehensive characterization revealed remarkable electrocatalytic metrics, including a half-wave potential of 0.88 V vs. RHE and a limiting current density of 5.65 mA/cm2. Synergistic Density Functional Theory (DFT) computations and multi-potential X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopic (XPS) analyses elucidated the intrinsic mechanistic landscape, conclusively identifying Te single atoms as primary catalytic centers and delineating the rate-determining reaction trajectory. This systematic investigation not only introduces an innovative paradigm for designing cost-effective non-metallic catalysts but also provides fundamental mechanistic insights into the intricate relationship between active site localization and catalytic performance, thereby advancing our fundamental understanding of site-specific catalysis in two-dimensional materials.
